lines.text: The only thing I ever put in my orange juice is gin.
Gin?
Oh, uh, doctor's orders.
You have some kind of a condition?
No, no. Me and my doctor just like to get drunk together.
[Eric dials his home phone number from a payphone rest stop]

[into the phone]
Hello?

[into the phone]
Oh, hello Mr. Blanchard. Is my father in?
He's not here. Your father and the "new" Mrs. Dean, number six, left from Reno two days ago on their sunny honeymoon to Acapulco, Mexico.

[groans]
He went and did it again, huh? He didn't say if he was planning to stop in Palm Springs for a couple of days?
No, he didn't mention it.
He does know that I'm staying here and where to locate me?
Yes, yes, I told him twice as you requested.
Well, if he calls give him a message. Just tell him that, "Eric sends his regards".
Sure, I'll give him the message.
No, wait. Better make it "your son".
Your son?
"your son sends his regards". "Eric" may not ring a bell.
[Eric angrily hangs up]
Well, now, is this where we slap leather, cowboy? Would you be satisfied with a few loose teeth?
I don't know where you was raised, mister, but where I come from, we don't start fights in other folks' homes.
The trouble with me is I put women on a pedestal.
Well, you gotta stop going out with short women. Ha-ha-ha. For instance, what happens when you talk to a girl about sex?
I get the hiccups.
Goodbye, darling.
[Kisses his wife, Cora]
I'll try to get home for dinner.
Remember your blood pressure, dear.
Don't panic, Cora. It's the beginning of a gay week. Ha-ha.

Room 204. House rules are on the back of the closet door. But, I've got two special ones. Number one. You come in here with liquor on your breath and I'll throw you out on your rudder. Number two. No cross-pollination with members of the opposite sex.
Hello.
Oh, you're a young one.
I'm 21. Would you like to see my driver's license?
Please, every Easter this town is filled with 21 year old teenagers. Did you come about the job or did you want a room?
I'd like a room please.
I have one bed left in a double room. 12 dollars a day.
Oh.
Too steep for you?
Well, do you have anything less expensive?
I'm sorry.
George.
Yes, Mr. Dean.
We're thirsty, George. Bring us two specials.
I beg your pardon, Mr. Dean, but I have to ask the young lady for some identification.
Young lady, the jig's up. Identify yourself. Thought you could pull a fast one, huh?
Sir.
[Hands Eric her wallet]
Alright George, take notes. This is Miss Gayle Lewis, 6150 Rexford Drive, Beverly Hills, California. Got that, George?
Yes sir.
She's 5 foot 2. Weighs 100 pounds. How 'bout that, George?
Very good, sir.
Very good? My dear man, that's perfect!
Do you think you could stay away from girls for seven years?
I manage to have a few dates. One cannot ignore the biological urges, you know.
Would you want the girl you expect to marry to indulge in her biological urges, too?
No.
In the meantime, you're not adverse to the experiences yourself.
Ruthie, how'd you ever get your Mom's okay?

I didn't. She and Dad went to Vegas for a few days. Now, look, there's beer and soft drinks in the kitchen. The bedrooms are off limits. And if you want to go in the pool, you're going to have to wear a suit.
Darling, you didn't tell me this was going to be a formal affair.
But, of course.

I propose a toast! I drink to the Easter orphans. To all of us wicked little children banded together on the beaches and resorts from Florida to California to observe the rites of Spring. Here's to Sex, sand and suds. Enjoy them!
